Award.AwardTitle: Multi-constituent inhibitory systems with self-organizing properties
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates several important binary and ternary systems with self-organizing properties, with an emphasis on ternary systems and the longer ranging confinement mechanism through nonlocal interaction or inhibitor variables. One intriguing feature that sets ternary systems apart from binary systems is the triple junction phenomenon. The three constituents of the system may meet at a point in the two dimensional case or at a curve in the three dimensional case. The PI proposes to show the existence of a double bubble assembly pattern, where the triple junction phenomenon occurs in each double bubble. Two novel techniques, restricted perturbation classes and internal variables, will be used in the proof. The second feature in ternary systems is the complexity of the long range interaction manifested in a two by two matrix of parameters. For instance it will be shown that the core-shell pattern appears only if the 2-2 entry is greater than the 1-2 entry of the matrix. When multi-constituent inhibitory systems appear in a curved space, such as a vesicle of lipid membranes, the role played by the Riemann curvature will also be investigated. Patterns and their possible defects will be shown as a balance and compromise of growth, inhibition, and curvature.

Exquisitely structured patterns arise in many multi-constituent physical and biological systems as orderly outcomes of self-organization principles. Examples include morphological phases in block copolymers, animal coats, and skin pigmentation. Common in these pattern-forming systems is that a deviation from homogeneity has a strong positive feedback on its further increase. On its own, it would lead to an unlimited increase and spreading. Pattern formation requires in addition a longer ranging confinement of the locally self-enhancing process. This project derives geometrical patterns from self-organization principles in various binary and ternary physical and biological systems. Analysis of these geometric structures is a fundamental step in understanding the mechanical, optical, electrical, ionic, barrier and other properties of these systems. This project supports a culturally diverse environment that fosters critical and independent thinking both in classroom and research settings in the ethnically diverse metropolitan area of Washington, DC. It produces mathematics of depth and beauty, and offers profound insights into the natural world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studies physical and biological systems with self-organization properties that produce morphological phases or patterns. Common in these systems is that a deviation from homogeneity has a strong positive feedback on its further increase, and in the meantime a longer ranging confinement mechanism exists to limit increase and spreading. As a result, exquisitely structured patterns, known as morphological phases in materials science and morphologcial patterns in development biology,  arise as orderly outcomes of self-organization principles. Examples include block copolymers, animal coats, and skin pigmentation. Morphology patterns determine mechanical, optical, electrical, ionic, barrier and other properties of the underlining systems. For instance, block copolymers are commercially used as thermoplastic elastomers: wine bottle stoppers, jelly candles, outer coverings foroptical fibre cables, adhesives, bitumen modifiers, or in artificial organ technology.

Two morphological phases are discovered mathematically for triblock copolymers, which are ternary systems with three constitutive species. One is the core-shell phase modeled by core-shell assemblies as stable stationary points of the free energy funcitonal of triblock copolymers. The second is the double bubble phase modeled by double bubble assemblies as stable stationary points of the same free energy. 

Also studied are some binary systems of two constitutive species. One of them is the diblock copolymer problem for which a toroidal phase is investigated. This phase should be modeled by stationary assemblies of tori. Each torus is a solution of a profile problem. The existence of a torus profile was established in an earlier study. In this project, the stability property is determined. It turns out that this profile is unstable for a subtle reason, so the current model for diblock copolymers need to be revised in order to understand the toroidal phase.

Interestingly the diblock copolymer problem is also derived from the Gierer-Meinhardt system, which is an activator-inhibitor type reaction diffusion system of partial differential equations. It was first introduced to model the head formation of hydra. More generally it can be used to study morphogenesis in cell development.  It provides a theoretical bridge between observations on the one hand and the deduction of the underlying molecular-genetic mechanisms on the other hand.

Another binary system studied in this project is related to the FItzHugh-Nagumo system. The FitzHugu-Nagumo problem was originally proposed for excitable systems such as neuron fields. It now serves as a prototype model for patterns like stripes, spots, traveling fronts, traveling pulses, etc, from homogeneous media destabilized by a spatial modulation. This project investigates disc assemblies for the FitzHugh-Nagumo system in two dimensions and ball assemblies in three dimensions. In each case, one first studies a profile problem that contains two parameters. The existence and stability of a disc in 2D or a ball in 3D depend sensitively on the two paramters. In 2D there may be zero, one, two, or even three disc profiles for a given pair of parameters. In 3D, one can have zero, one, two, but not three ball profiles for a given pair of parameters. Some of the disc profiles or ball profiles are stable while others are unstable. The stable ones can be used as a building block for a component in a stable stationary disc (or ball) assembly. 

The analytic approach to self-organization phenomena in this project produces mathematics of depth and beauty, and offers profound insights into the nature of the physical world. Geometric structures like tori and double bubbles have been studied by geometers and topologists  for  their intrinsic beauty and the deep and diverse mathematical theories that they lead to.  The fact that these theories can be applied to real world problems makes them even more intriguing.

The education of three PhD students has been supported by this grant. Four publications/preprints are coauthored by the PI and these students. Two of them have received their PhD's degrees and their theses inlcude topics that originate from this project.

This grant has also supported the training of one postdoctoral scientist. In a joint paper of the PI and the postdoc, a fully nonlocal model is proposed and studied. It generalizes the existing hybrid models, like the FitzHugh-Nagumo system, for competing short distance and long distance interaction properties, into a unified framework. Discontinuous patterns, which do not exist in hybrid models, now exist as stable stationary points. 

The resutls obtained in this projects have generated much interest in the applied mathematics community of pattern formation researchers. The PI has given more than 20 lectures at conferences during the grant period to present these results. Five publications and three preprints authored by the PI and his collaborators report the findings from this project.
